Product Package Content Inside the package was: The SSD itself A protective case for the SSD Two extra thicc USB 3.0 cables: USB type C - USB type C cable USB type C - USB type A cable A little manual #skipthetutorial ðŸ™ƒ Benchmarks As soon as it arrived, I ran a few benchmark tests on the external SSD.
item.content:
Introduction

Yesterday my Beetle X31 SSD was delivered. I ordered it because it was heavily discounted on the black friday sale (70â‚¬). I ordered the 1TB Version to extend my external storage possibility as far as possible.

Product

Package Content

Inside the package was:

  • The SSD itself
  • A protective case for the SSD
  • Two extra thicc USB 3.0 cables:
    • USB type C - USB type C cable
    • USB type C - USB type A cable
  • A little manual #skipthetutorial ðŸ™ƒ

Benchmarks

As soon as it arrived, I ran a few benchmark tests on the external SSD. Here are the results: … And yes, I used Windows 4 this As you can see, the results are really great and the Beetle X31 SSD is performing as advertised.

Conclusion

The Beetle X31 SSD is a high performing external SSD at a low price range. I totally recommend buying it, especially when in discount.

item.title: My first blog entry
item.description: This is the first entry in my blog. I am testing a few things here: Get it to work Get images to work Get Code to be displayed properly Get publishing to work Images Here is an image of my beautiful desktop environment: Code System.out.println("Hello, world!");
item.content:
This is the first entry in my blog. I am testing a few things here:

  1. Get it to work
  2. Get images to work
  3. Get Code to be displayed properly
  4. Get publishing to work

Images

Here is an image of my beautiful desktop environment:

Code

System.out.println("Hello, world!");

item.title: The idea behind this
item.description: I always wanted to develop a post where I could write inspiring stuff about my life and programming carrier. But the problem always was, that hosting a big ass web app with a database and everything would result in high hosting cost. To avoid this, I came up with this solution: I write my posts in Markdown I translate the Markdown to HTML using Hugo I run a custom bash script to polish everything off I automatically publish the site to Vercel through a GitHub push
item.content:
I always wanted to develop a post where I could write inspiring stuff about my life and programming carrier. But the problem always was, that hosting a big ass web app with a database and everything would result in high hosting cost. To avoid this, I came up with this solution:

  • I write my posts in Markdown
  • I translate the Markdown to HTML using Hugo
  • I run a custom bash script to polish everything off
  • I automatically publish the site to Vercel through a GitHub push
